@briankardell but polyfills are only insane b/c they're built on the foolish notion that we should have all these auto globals.

@briankardell is it too late? shouldn't be too late to stop making a mistake. quit adding to the global space.

@briankardell node should let me import a process module and call it whatever the eff i want. JS should let me access `global` w/ any name
@briankardell the only real solution is for environments to stop adding any identifiers, and provide only one mechanism for import
@briankardell and as we're seeing, even telling people just to avoid adding globals of a certain name isn't safe enough.
@briankardell people will name stuff as it makes sense at the time.
@briankardell but i don't see how the spec saying "please don't use 'generic likely to conflict names'..please!" is gonna do anything.

@briankardell so, at some point, an env is practically synonymous with the language. same if a browser API conflicted.

@briankardell given long enough (the future is much longer than the past), there's far more space for eventual collision.

(related) in defense of anonymous subtweeting over quote-tweeting:

may still offend the person, but at least it doesn't crowd-bully them.
i'm attracted to JS b/c i love more freedom. but i do lament the exhaustion from trying to evangelize and adhere to responsible usage.
and i understand the attraction many feel to more strongly typed langs, b/c none of this nonsense is even possible.
but more importantly, linters can't actually save you from your own ignorance. they only make it harder to spot.
linters are great, but they're not supposed to be a substitute for you knowing what you do and why.
and then, instead of learning and critically thinking, many just fall back on "good parts" cult and blanket linter rules.
much of the criticism JS faces as a language can be traced to its flexibility to be used in totally bastardized ways.
i love JS and its types and coercion and all that. but we've got way too much damn laziness around how to use them properly.

"it's too hard in JS for me to know what the type in a variable will be."

O_o

stop using JS. you need a diff language.

(blatant subtweet)
@nickhudkins @mpjme yeah, often DRYing leads to clever polymorphisms that end up making code way more complex to read.
